Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: cPAP device for premature infants
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader/commercial impact of this I-Corps project is to potentially reduce significantly the number of deaths of premature babies in low to middle income countries. Premature birth is globally the number one cause of death in children under the age of 5, with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) being the leading cause of these deaths. RDS is usually addressed by using a bCPAP (bubble continuous positive airway pressure) machine that provides the baby with a humidified blend of air and oxygen at a controlled temperature and pressure. The goal of this project is to develop a state-of-the-art, low-cost bCPAP machine that aids preterm babies in low to middle income countries. While bCPAP devices are standard in wealthy nations, their $8-10k cost often makes them unaffordable for countries with fewer resources.

This I-Corps project will explore the commercial potential of a novel bubble continuous positive airway pressure (bCPAP) machine. Some of the innovative features of this device include a cassette format for ease of maintenance and repair, a battery backup for uninterrupted care, robust component selection for extended lifetime use and a drug delivery add on for potential treatment of comorbidities. If successfully implemented, this product would potentially help provide quality affordable healthcare to underserved populations and reduce premature deaths due to respiratory distress syndrome.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development and generation of new medical devices tends to be expensive and leads most companies to produce high-priced products and services for high income markets. Low to middle income countries (LMIC) often lack the resources to secure expensive high-priced medical equipment, if they are able to afford these devices, they often lack the necessary training and customer support services to ensure these machines function optimally and are meeting their needs. The main goal of Therapeutic Innovations is to redesign medical devices for developing countries. Our combined flagship product will be designed to optimize neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) training for staff and provide the infant respiratory breathing system called the AirBaby​.   The introduction of our AirBaby device, would be able to help reduce the infant mortality rate. The NSF I CORP program allowed team memebers to learn important evidence-based customery discovery skills that was very useful during our fact finding tour which took us to Africa and India. During our trips we interacted with clinicians, patients and mothers across various healthcare facilities across both countries. We identifed key issues with the premature patient managment process which challeneged our initial hypothesis.These key findings include but not limited to the following: 

  1. A lack of knowledge and understanding by primary caregivers of NICU processes,specifically treatemnet of RDS.  Preliminary findings revealed by our survey that the nurses have learned their skills by observing other staff workers.  There are a few nurses who have received some formal nursing training, however, on the job training seems to be the standard.
  2. There were no continous positive airway pressure devices (CPAP) units.  The delivery of  CPAP  was often attempted by ventilators not designed for those applications in its optimal fashion. Most of the clincian are misinformed by sales representatives.These representatives are often only interested in making a sale, disregarding a complete needs analysis.  It wasn?t uncommon for us to see a graveyard of sophisticated machines unused, in closets, or in undersized rooms piled on top of each other.  Many of the devices require constant repeat disposable purchases which are costly and many do not meet the needs of the establishment. 
  3. The clinical engineering teams are in desperate need of organizing their equipment and enhancing their understanding of which disposables are necessary for neonatal devices. 

These findings in addition to others informed new product specifications and help shape the future of our venture. With a successfully evidence-based customer discovery program we have applied for the Phase 1 SBIR to help develop our prototype and also develop a comprehensive education program to help clincians in LMIC better understand the neonate patient managment process.


Last Modified: 01/02/2020
Modified by: Solomon Mensah

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The development and generation of new medical devices tends to be expensive and leads most companies to produce high-priced products and services for high income markets. Low to middle income countries (LMIC) often lack the resources to secure expensive high-priced medical equipment, if they are able to afford these devices, they often lack the necessary training and customer support services to ensure these machines function optimally and are meeting their needs. The main goal of Therapeutic Innovations is to redesign medical devices for developing countries. Our combined flagship product will be designed to optimize neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) training for staff and provide the infant respiratory breathing system called the AirBaby​. The introduction of our AirBaby device, would be able to help reduce the infant mortality rate. The NSF I CORP program allowed team memebers to learn important evidence-based customery discovery skills that was very useful during our fact finding tour which took us to Africa and India. During our trips we interacted with clinicians, patients and mothers across various healthcare facilities across both countries. We identifed key issues with the premature patient managment process which challeneged our initial hypothesis.These key findings include but not limited to the following: A lack of knowledge and understanding by primary caregivers of NICU processes,specifically treatemnet of RDS. Preliminary findings revealed by our survey that the nurses have learned their skills by observing other staff workers. There are a few nurses who have received some formal nursing training, however, on the job training seems to be the standard. There were no continous positive airway pressure devices (CPAP) units. The delivery of CPAP was often attempted by ventilators not designed for those applications in its optimal fashion. Most of the clincian are misinformed by sales representatives.These representatives are often only interested in making a sale, disregarding a complete needs analysis. It wasn?t uncommon for us to see a graveyard of sophisticated machines unused, in closets, or in undersized rooms piled on top of each other. Many of the devices require constant repeat disposable purchases which are costly and many do not meet the needs of the establishment. The clinical engineering teams are in desperate need of organizing their equipment and enhancing their understanding of which disposables are necessary for neonatal devices. These findings in addition to others informed new product specifications and help shape the future of our venture. With a successfully evidence-based customer discovery program we have applied for the Phase 1 SBIR to help develop our prototype and also develop a comprehensive education program to help clincians in LMIC better understand the neonate patient managment process.
